explanation:
The correct calculation for \( \tan(30^\circ) \) uses the 30-60-90 triangle ratios: opposite side = 1, adjacent side = \( \sqrt{3} \), hypotenuse = 2. Thus, \( \tan(30^\circ) = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \).

The student likely calculated \( \frac{1}{2} \) by incorrectly using the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse (\( \frac{1}{2} \)) instead of the opposite to adjacent. This indicates they conflated the definitions of sine and tangent. 

The error directly stems from misapplying the trigonometric ratios: they used the sine ratio (SOH) instead of the tangent ratio (TOA). This is distinct from swapping adjacent/opposite sides (which would yield \( \sqrt{3} \)) or confusing cosine for sine. The core flaw is failing to distinguish which sides correspond to "opposite over adjacent" in the tangent ratio.
